image.altText: A lightning strike

props.synopsis: A child is in a critical condition as Queensland continues to battle wild weather.

title.children: A 10-year-old Sunshine Coast girl is in hospital after being struck by lightning

image.altText: a man on a porch

props.synopsis: ABC News has exclusively traced a devastating case of financial crime described as "bizarre". It comes as the financial watchdog reveals that investment scams are on the rise in Australia.

title.children: Inside the 'growing threat' to self-managed super that could leave Australians out of pocket with no compensation

image.altText: Man looks at his phone

props.synopsis: When John Carter was moving into care earlier this year, his family was sorting through his belongings and made an alarming discovery.

title.children: 'Pushy' tele-fundraisers pressure pensioner into donating $18k as family calls for crackdown

image.altText: engin and ariyak

props.synopsis: Forty-three years ago, eight-year-old Cagla Ariyak and her mother waved goodbye to her father from the front door of their Sydney home. Seconds later, Sarık Arıyak would be shot dead, alongside his bodyguard Engin Sever.

title.children: A $1 million reward and a mystery phone call — a Sydney assassination remains unsolved four decades later

image.altText: A composite image shows the detained men on the left, and a portrait of Hani on the right.

props.synopsis: When Hani Almadhoun heard his brother had been taken by troops in Gaza, he went online to investigate — and spotted the shopkeeper among near-naked captives in a video going viral.

title.children: 'These are not Hamas people': How an aid worker spotted his terrified brother in a viral video from Gaza

image.altText: A composite of three images of men, one of them smiling

props.synopsis: The Israeli military says on Friday its soldiers found three hostages in Gaza City and erroneously identified them as a threat, but it is not clear whether they had escaped their captors or been abandoned.

title.children: Israeli military says mistakenly killed hostages were holding white flags

image.altText: Mitchell Starc on the field wearing his whites and a floppy hat

props.synopsis: The events of day three will likely end up assuring Australia of first Test victory over Pakistan in Perth, but they also set the scene for what is now shaping up to be a very intriguing summer.

title.children: As Australia takes control in Perth, the stories of this summer begin to reveal themselves

image.altText: A man in a blue suit holding binoculars to his face

props.synopsis: After a controversial Netflix drama triggered a debate about schoolyard bullies in South Korea, this private detective has been inundated with queries from concerned parents asking him to tail their children.

title.children: For $5,000 a week, this investigator follows school children around to identify their bullies

image.altText: A photo illustration showing champagne, mini pavlovas, cheese, bread and roast turkey with prawn in shape of dollar signs

props.synopsis: Persistent inflation over the last couple of years means the cost of turkey, ham, prawns and Christmas pudding are all a lot more expensive than they used to be.

title.children: Two staples are considerably more expensive this Christmas

image.altText: A blonde woman with short hair sits in an all black outfit against a white wall on a stool and half smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: The world has progressed in many ways, but in 2023 many women fear parenthood more than ever before, with the belief that their career and baby won't co-exist.

title.children: Career or baby? The workplace discrimination women fear when falling pregnant

image.altText: Cardinal wearing red robes holds hand to his face

props.synopsis: In an historic trial, Angelo Becciu is the highest-ranking Catholic Church official to stand trial before a Vatican criminal court.

title.children: Vatican jails cardinal who was once a papal contender for fraud over London property deal

image.altText: Aerial view of two people eating a parma at a pub.

props.synopsis: A group of graduating uni friends made a plan to stay in touch at regular pub nights, a tradition which has now lasted two decades — helped along by good planning, intergenerational fun and a strict chicken parma rule.

title.children: As people grow older, friendships can drift apart. But this group of former uni mates reckon they've got the solution

image.altText: A young man in a hospital bed with tubes connected to his throat and teddy bear nearby

props.synopsis: Dylan Meyer didn't think he'd be alive for Christmas after a mosquito bite left him on life support. He now wants others to heed his warning.

title.children: Dylan thought it was 'just another mosquito bite'. He went on to spend four months on life support

image.altText: A family of four taking a selfie in front of the ocean.

props.synopsis: Some parents are having to fly in carers from interstate due to lack of childcare services in South Australian towns. It comes as research is launched into the depth of the shortfalls.

title.children: Parents fly in family to look after kids due to lack of regional childcare

image.altText: A pile of Australian Licence Plates

props.synopsis: Automatic number plate recognition cameras are used by police to detect stolen cars and owners wanted for crimes. But their usefulness drops sharply once an offender crosses a state or territory border.

title.children: The loophole criminals are using to evade police — and there are no plans to close it

image.altText: presents

props.synopsis: The cost-of-living crisis, Australia's changing demographics, and the greater mobility of the country's population mean the way we celebrate Christmas is now very different to how we did 50 years ago.

title.children: How has Christmas changed in 50 years and what does this year's look like with cost-of-living pressures?

image.altText: A man wearing traditional Arab red and white head scarf and golden gown

props.synopsis: The cause of death was not immediately disclosed, but last month he was admitted to hospital. His half-brother is the designated successor.

title.children: Kuwait's ruling emir dies at age 86, three years after assuming power

image.altText: A close up of a smiling Matthew Perry, wearing clear plastic-rimmed glasses, a black suit jacked and a grey v-neck shirt.

props.synopsis: The LA medical examiner says Perry also drowned in "the heated end of his pool" but that it was a secondary factor in his October 28 death, which was deemed an accident.

title.children: Matthew Perry autopsy reveals Friends actor's cause of death

image.altText: A child in a santa hat and beard holds a leg of ham half his own body size

props.synopsis: Roads, rates and rubbish are generally the cornerstone of local government, but the Cherbourg Aboriginal Shire Council in Queensland has added ham deliveries to its operations to bring some much-needed cheer.

title.children: Local council gives every household a free leg of ham for Christmas after difficult year

props.synopsis: Australia makes the perfect start to day three against Pakistan, but leaves Nathan Lyon one wicket away from joining an exclusive club. Here are five quick hits from the first Test at Perth Stadium.

title.children: Five quick hits — Warner comes down from cloud nine and Lyon is stranded on 499

image.altText: The daly River and some trees.

props.synopsis: Ingrid and her family can't afford to buy bottled water, so when the taps runs a dirty brown, tainted by iron and manganese, they don't drink it.

title.children: The water in this remote Northern Territory community intermittently runs 'very dark brown'

image.altText: An aerial view of Tuvalu.

props.synopsis: Australians have been left stranded in Tuvalu after Fiji Airways cancelled all flights to and from the tiny Pacific Island national indefinitely due to damage to the airport's runway.

title.children: Concerns travellers stranded in Tuvalu by damaged airport runway could run out of cash

image.altText: A group of women in pink headbands and white shirts sing.

props.synopsis: Twila Whittingham always thought of music as medicine, so when doctors found a pre-cancerous tumour in her breast mid-last year, she knew she would need more than conventional treatment to cope.

title.children: 'Boob choir' spreads joy and awareness about breast cancer through song

image.altText: A woman wearing an orange suit smiles with a microphone in front of her.

props.synopsis: Maybe it's the celebrity touch, but the public fascination with Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case has only increased this week, as journalist Lisa Wilkinson was cross-examined by Mr Lehrmann's barrister.

title.children: Lisa Wilkinson's evidence provided compelling viewing as she locked horns with Bruce Lehrmann's lawyers

image.altText: Premier Steven Miles with Deputy Premier Cameron Dick standing behind him

props.synopsis: The next Queensland election is less than a year away and, now he's taken over the top, job Steven Miles is keen to avoid facing the final curtain at the ballot box, writes Rachel Riga.

title.children: He was Palaszczuk's right hand man. As premier, Steven Miles is out to do it his way

image.altText: A man with a wide open mouth leans into a hamburger

props.synopsis: When we change our diet and start losing weight, we disrupt how our appetite hormones function. Here's how you can stay on track, writes Nick Fuller.

title.children: I want to lose weight and eat healthily. So why do I feel hungry all the time?

image.altText: A person looks at a packet of chips in a supermarket or convenience store.

props.synopsis: When ultra-processed foods first hit supermarket shelves, people weren't convinced they were real food. Now many Australians depend on them.

title.children: Experts say we've become dependent on ultra-processed foods. How did we get here?

image.altText: A photo taken by an observatory showing a large solar flare creating a bright flash on the surface of the Sun

props.synopsis: A NASA telescope captures the biggest solar flare since 2017, which scientists are calling an "amazing event".

title.children: Biggest solar flare in years temporarily disrupts communications on Earth in 'never seen before' occurrence

image.altText: A giant solved Rubiks Cube sits on the beach with surfer and walker behind

props.synopsis: Residents awoke to find the mystery of Maroubra Beach's iconic Rubik's Cube finally solved but the new look of this much-loved piece of street art is dividing local opinion.

title.children: After 15 years, one of Sydney’s biggest puzzles has been solved but not everyone is happy

image.altText: Four Taliban fighters ride in the back of a car in the darnkess, holding assault rifles

props.synopsis: State-sponsored women protection centres have disappeared after the Taliban takeover in 2021, the report says, and the group now sends women to prison if they have no male relatives to stay with or if the male relatives are considered unsafe.

title.children: Taliban sending Afghan women to prison to protect them from gender-based violence, says UN report

image.altText: A group of people dressed in black surrounding a blue dot-painted casket being lowered into the ground.

props.synopsis: West Australian teen Cleveland Dodd has been laid to rest, but his family still have questions about the circumstances surrounding his death. Four decades earlier, the relatives of 16-year-old John Pat had similar concerns after the boy died in police custody.

title.children: Decades apart, tragedy lingers: The troubling similarities in the deaths of two Indigenous teens

image.altText: People wait with their luggage while sitting on bench seats at the airport.

props.synopsis: Airlines and popular travel destinations are offering unique solutions to ditching cumbersome luggage in an effort to either reduce their travel footprint or the impact of tourism on local communities. Here are some of them.

title.children: Renting clothes on holiday and ditching wheeled luggage: The future of travel could be carry-on only

image.altText: flood waters beneath a street of houses

props.synopsis: A "dog's breakfast" is how a North Queensland councillor has described the Australian Warning System during Ex-Tropical Cyclone Jasper. The government admits it needs fine tuning.

title.children: New warning system leaves cyclone residents panicked, in heightened state of fear

image.altText: man in rain jacket holding large barramundi

props.synopsis: Thousands of dead barramundi could start washing up through the Redlynch Valley in Cairns over the coming days following the removal of a spillway net from Copperlode Dam, the city's main water supply.

title.children: Dam waste: Fears for local barramundi and water supply due to cyclone safety net removal

image.altText: Seven warriors stand in a field, with a large ringed planet in the background.

props.synopsis: Everything you need to know about the latest Netflix blockbuster, which was almost a Star Wars spin-off.

title.children: What is Rebel Moon, the new straight-to-streaming blockbuster by Zack Snyder?
